;中国呼吁和平、反对霸权和“通过对话弥合分歧”，与朝鲜一起纪念朝鲜战争停火 70 周年。

;

;随着北京的一个高级代表团于周三抵达平壤，中国官方媒体发布了一系列纪念 1950-53 年战争的文章参加相关活动，这是中国官员在疫情后首次访问朝鲜。

;

;代表团由中共中央政治局委员、中共中央政治局常委、中央政治局常委李鸿忠率领。中国最高立法机关全国人民代表大会是执政的共产党的权力中心。

;

;由国防部长谢尔盖·绍伊古率领的俄罗斯代表团早些时候抵达平壤参加庆祝活动，朝鲜希望在美国及其盟国在该地区加强军事活动的情况下，加强与两个主要伙伴的关系。

;

;2018 年，习近平派出他的得力助手、时任全国人大常委会委员长、第三届全国人大常委会委员长栗战书。中共最高决策机构政治局常务委员会的高级官员出席朝鲜成立 70 周年庆祝活动。

;

;选择级别较低的李鸿忠暗示习近平可能想淡化北京方面的说法

;

;上海政法大学教授倪乐雄表示：“与[俄罗斯总统]普京派国防部长绍伊古的决定相比，这次出席李鸿忠的讲话反映了中美之间的微妙关系，因为北京不想激怒华盛顿，双方都在努力改善关系。”

;

;平壤周四举行了一次军事集会，以纪念这一事件。 1953年停战协定签署的这一天被称为“胜利日”。中国和前苏联都在联合国旗帜下支持朝鲜对美国、韩国其他军队进行战争，至少有18万中国军人阵亡.

;

;中国国家通讯社新华社在周三的一篇社论中将停战协议描述为和平和人民对抗“美帝国主义”入侵的胜利。声明称，在“冷战思维和强权政治依然存在”的世界里，中国始终主张和平稳定。

;

;“世界再次站在历史的十字路口……世界并不太平。”和平需要捍卫，正义需要捍卫。

;

;“中国共产党带领中国人民始终致力于维护国际公平正义、促进世界和平朝鲜领导人金正恩周四回应了中国反对霸权主义和帝国主义的信息。据朝鲜官方机构朝中社报道，他告诉李克强，他永远不会忘记70年前“为胜利而流血”的中国“勇敢的战士”。

;

;报道称，金正恩参观了平壤的一座墓地周三，金正恩还与绍伊古举行了单独会面，两人视察了朝鲜韩国的最新武器 - 包括火星导弹和类似于美国 RQ-4 全球鹰无人机的间谍无人机。

;

;中国热门电影《昌津湖之战》即将拍摄续集

;

;白宫还发表了一份纪念退伍军人和美韩联盟的声明。

;

;李克强的访问正值以美国为首的西方加大对中国施压以帮助遏制朝鲜的军事野心之际。

;

;李克强的访问正值以美国为首的西方加大对中国施压之际。 >;

;美国国务卿安东尼·布林肯上周警告称，如果中国不利用其“独特影响力”帮助朝鲜半岛无核化，华盛顿将寻求与日本和韩国建立更紧密的防务联盟。

;

;七国集团、欧盟和其他几个国家在周五的一封信中集体敦促中国帮助阻止朝鲜通过中国领海逃避联合国制裁。

;

;作为回应，中国常驻联合国代表团北京周一表示，“严格”执行联合国安理会决议。

;

;自 2006 年以来，由于联合国对其核计划和弹道导弹计划实施制裁，朝鲜与世界的贸易基本上被切断，中国和俄罗斯也因此陷入困境。其重要的政治和贸易伙伴。双方都反对对平壤实施进一步制裁。

;

;周四，李克强告诉金正恩，中国愿意“促进（双边）关系健康稳定发展，给两国人民带来幸福，据韩国联合通讯社报道，李克强还转交了习近平的一封信。其内容并未透露。

;

;习近平和金正恩有着交换私人信件的悠久传统。习近平最后一次致信金正恩是在 11 月，回应韩国领导人获得历史性第三个任期的贺电。

;

;朝中社援引习近平在信中承诺与金正恩共同致力于地区稳定的内容。 ，这是在平壤为回应美韩围绕朝鲜半岛的军演而进行一系列导弹试验后不久进行的。

;中美军舰和军机之间越来越频繁的相遇很难分析，因为一位美国军事分析家周三表示，其中一些事件没有被报道。

;

;“谈论[美中军事事件]的部分挑战是许多遭遇没有被报道，”约西亚·凯斯(Josiah Case)，海军分析中心的一位研究分析师在华盛顿智库布鲁金斯学会周三举行的一次活动上表示。

;

;“这就是为什么很难说除了[五角大楼]官员在公开场合告诉我们的内容。

;

;“需要记住的一件事是我们过去几个月在海上和空中看到的事件，这些事件[人民解放军]的不专业行为已经不是第一次了。

;

;“我认为我们今天所看到的情况如此令人担忧的部分原因是这些都是在真空中发生的。”

;

;美国官员表示，由于两国军队之间缺乏高层沟通，中美巡逻舰艇和飞机之间的遭遇变得越来越危险。去年8月美国前众议院议长南希·佩洛西访问台湾后，北京切断了多个沟通渠道。

;

;6月初，一艘中国军舰在台湾海峡接近一艘美国驱逐舰137米（150码）以内，并迫使此前五角大楼曾于 5 月份声称，一架中国战斗机在南海国际空域拦截美国间谍机时进行了“不必要的侵略性动作”。

;

;北京反驳了这些指控，将美国在南海地区的军事行动定性为挑衅。

;

;中国外交部发言人毛宁在战斗机事件发生后表示，“这种挑衅和危险行为最近，印度-太平洋司令部司令约翰·阿奎利诺海军上将在科罗拉多州阿斯彭安全论坛上表示，与中国人民解放军同行联系的尝试已被忽视中国航天公司研究总监罗德里克·李（Roderick Lee）表示，这些事态发展意味着北京不太可能恢复与美国军方的正式联系。美国空军航空大学下属研究所在布鲁金斯学会的讨论中表示。

;

;李表示，北京根据对该地区的定期空中和海上巡逻得出了有关美国意图的自己的结论，因此认为直接会谈没有什么价值。

;

;“就价值而言，你在电话中所说的内容可能是最不重要的……所以我认为他们没有任何改善正式沟通的意图，因为我认为他们认为这已经非常好，”他说。

;

;“他们可能认为我们真的很擅长通过这些非语言线索进行交流。

;

;“我们是否是或不是是另一个问题。我认为这就是危险所在。”

;

;观察人士表示，鉴于解放军的军事野心以及美国不愿撤回在太平洋地区的活动，频繁的冲突可能会继续下去。

;< p>;“如果我们要撤回我们的行动……或者近距离侦察，如果我们要撤回这些行动以试图表达善意，我确实认为北京会认为这是一个弱点，”凯斯说。

;

;然而，尽管两位分析师都强调了在中国大陆附近的行动不断增加的情况下缺乏军事对话所带来的风险，但他们也注意到解放军飞行员表现出了更高水平的专业精神。

;

;李以2001年美国EP-3侦察机与中国战斗机在海南岛附近相撞的事件进行了比较。解放军 J-8 喷气式飞机的飞行员在此次事件中丧生。

;

;李表示，解放军“拥有更熟练的飞行员，这将导致他们现在以成熟的方式指导尝试让美国停止或至少对美国的侦察行动表示不满”。

;

;案件同意。

;

;“解放军正在成为一支更加专业的军队，但这并不意味着操作员错误并没有完全消失，”他说。

;马来西亚周四宣布了一项激进计划，租赁屋顶安装太阳能，因为政府力求到 2050 年将全国可再生能源的份额提高到总发电量的 70%。

;

;这个概念是向家庭支付屋顶空间用于产生太阳能的费用。这是政府打算根据国家能源转型路线图 (NETR) 实施的多项措施之一。

;

;该路线图“旨在打破陈规，使清洁能源成为大多数家庭经济上相关的选择”今天”，经济部长拉菲兹·拉姆利 (Rafizi Ramli) 说道。

;

;“在每个家庭中，我们打算让家庭选择出租屋顶，以换取每月收入，这可以降低他们的电费并投入更多现金他们的口袋，”他说。

;

;马来西亚会将向新加坡的能源出口置于其绿色经济计划之前吗？

;

;马来西亚的电力仍然严重依赖煤炭和天然气。根据国际可再生​​能源机构 (Irena) 的数据，可再生能源占总发电量的 16%，主要来自水力发电装置。

;

;2021 年太阳能发电装机容量为 1,780 兆瓦，不到水坝发电 6,211 兆瓦的三分之一。

;

;Rafizi 拒绝透露他们预计从全国数百万家庭屋顶太阳能装置中获得多少电力的预测，并表示这将取决于他们能够在多大程度上说服马来西亚人加入该计划。

;

;目前，拉菲兹表示，住宅物业的屋顶太阳能计划将从在瓜拉郊区正在建设的新城镇进行试点项目开始吉隆坡由一家私人开发商负责管理，从与房主的租赁交易到在独立太阳能生态系统中的安装和电力存储。

;

;该项目预计将为 450 户家庭产生约 4.5 兆瓦的电力他说，政府无需支付任何费用。

;

;我们早期想要关注的是让更多此类综合性大型城市开发项目将太阳能纳入其整个定价方案中， ”拉菲兹在随后的新闻发布会上说道。 “然后，这将使他们能够研究能源存储解决方案（ESS），因为没有 ESS，这一切就不可能发生。”

;

;早些时候，拉菲兹还宣布了国家主权财富基金国库控股 (Khazanah Nasional) 与两家私人公司之间的一项协议马来西亚实体开发 1 吉瓦混合太阳能光伏电站，他称其为“东南亚最大的此类电站”。

;

;马来西亚最近取消了可再生能源出口禁令，旨在为自己定位作为该行业的区域领导者。此举使当地公司能够大规模发展产能并满足区域需求。

;

;总理安瓦尔·易卜拉欣此前曾呼吁为发展中国家提供更多资金，以帮助各国实现绿色目标。

; Thu, 27 Jul 2023 20:50:02 +0800 Risk of sleep disorder linked to neurodegeneration increases in those with family history of condition: Hong Kong studyhttps://www.scmp.com/news/hong-kong/health-environment/article/3229156/risk-sleep-disorder-linked-neurodegeneration-increases-those-family-history-condition-hong-kong?utm_source=rss_feed
;;2023.07.27 20:36;
;;

;Hong Kong retiree Pako Leung, 68, started having violent nightmares at least once a month a year after he was diagnosed with depression in 2010.

;

;“I dreamed that I was hurtling, and the next thing I knew I had rolled out of my bed. Once, I dreamed I was kicking something, and it turned out I had accidentally kicked the television next to my bed onto the ground,” he said.

;

;Leung was later diagnosed with REM Sleep Behaviour Disorder (RBD), a condition that causes people to physically and vocally act out their dreams He is now experiencing symptoms of neurodegeneration, including short-term memory loss, shaking hands and a poor sense of balance.

;

;In a study carried out by Chinese University, which released the findings on Thursday, Leung's younger brother, 65-year-old Patrick Leung, who was also diagnosed with depression and anxiety a few years ago, was found to have RBD.

;

;“I am less violent, but I dreamed of playing football and my wife told me I was kicking her in my sleep,” the younger Leung said.

;

;The four-year study looked at people with a family history of the sleep disorder, linked to depression and anxiety, and the chances of developing neurodegenerative diseases.

;

;It involved more than 1,300 family members of people with no psychiatric disorders, those with psychiatric disorders only and those with both psychiatric disorders and RBD.

;

;Hongkongers' happiness falls to 3-year low, poll finds, as experts warn of anxiety

;

;Researchers found that the risk of developing the sleeping disorder was two to 11 times higher in the relatives of people with both RBD and psychiatric disorders. The study was recently published in the Journal of Neurology, Neurosurgery and Psychiatry.

;

;Professor Wing Yun-kwok, chairman of the university medical faculty's department of psychiatry, said their study suggested that RBD could be used as a marker to predict the chances of developing neurodegenerative diseases, which did not have a cure.

;

;“This highlights the need to identify RBD among those with mental illnesses and prioritise them for preventive neurodegenerative measures,” Wing said.

;

;Previous studies have shown that 80 to 90 per cent of RBD patients develop neurodegenerative diseases, including Parkinson's, dementia and Alzheimer's, in the 15 years since their diagnosis.

;

;Hong Kong university builds case for using antidiabetic drug for anti-ageing

;

;Dr Huang Bei, research assistant professor in the university's department of psychiatry, said a different study had revealed that people who suffered from the sleeping disorder were 130 times more likely to develop Parkinson's disease.

;

;More than 300,000 people suffer from depression in Hong Kong and about 12,000 residents have Parkinson's disease.

;

;Only 0.7 to 1 per cent of older adults and elderly people in the city have RBD, but the figure is 10 times higher in those with depression.

;

;“RBD patients need to understand it's more than a simple sleep problem. It is associated with other risks. When patients understand this problem, they should not worry too much, but face it and look into preventive measures,” Wing said.

;

;Now aware of the risks of neurodegeneration, Leung said he would adopt a positive attitude and keep himself mentally and physically active, including practising Taiji to help improve his sense of balance and slow the progression of the condition.

;

;Patrick, who does not have any symptoms of neurodegeneration, said he would now pay more attention to the problem given the higher risks.

; Thu, 27 Jul 2023 20:20:02 +0800 WeChat tells Australian lawmakers China has never asked to spy on users, access private messageshttps://www.scmp.com/week-asia/politics/article/3229151/wechat-tells-australian-lawmakers-china-has-never-asked-spy-users-access-private-messages?utm_source=rss_feed

;;

;An Australian parliamentary inquiry into foreign interference convened by China hawks has been told by WeChat that Beijing had never made requests to snoop on Australian users or have access to private chat messages.

;

;The written response by the China-based superapp marks its first comment to the panel, after it declined to send a representative in person on account of not having permanent staff in Australia.

;

;In a bullet-point reply issued on Wednesday to 53 questions posed by the inquest's panel of lawmakers, the Tencent-owned platform also said Beijing could not monitor, moderate or censor any content or chats on WeChat as they were private, based in Singapore and bound by the city state's laws.

;

;“WeChat is a safe and secure platform, operated under Singapore laws, that enables private chat messages between users. Surveillance by any government would violate our stated policies,” WeChat said.

;

;Throughout its written response, WeChat reiterated that it had guidelines and policies only to the extent of providing users with a safe online space and practised similar approaches to other apps in prohibiting things like bullying and hate speech.

;

;It said it did not moderate content discussed by users – including Australians – that were sensitive to the Communist Party, such as violations against Muslims in Xinjiang or pro-democracy Hong Kong activism, but in line with its peers, it moderated specific content to prohibit “universally undesirable content” including fraud and nudity.

;

;The inquiry, set up late last year, is expected to release a report of its findings on August 1.

;

;WeChat to skip Australian social media hearing on 'political interference'

;

;Another popular China-linked app, TikTok, sent its Australian representatives to the previous hearing earlier this month and were grilled by Canberra lawmakers in scenes reminiscent of the congressional pile-on faced by TikTok's chief executive in the United States in March.

;

;Prominent China hawk, Australian senator James Paterson, who had sought to make the inquiry about China, questioned TikTok officials about China's alleged rights abuses in Xinjiang.

;

;WeChat was also asked in writing if it had an “official position on the governance of Taiwan”.

;

;The company said it was “unclear of the relevance of this question”.

;

;The inquiry also asked WeChat if it had taken down former Prime Minister Scott Morrison's account in January last year, just ahead of the Australian federal election in May.

;

;The company said there was no evidence of hacking or intrusion and the “incident in question centred on a dispute over account ownership of a Weixin official Account, not WeChat”, referencing to the distinction between the WeChat platform used by global users and Weixin – which is used on the Chinese mainland.

;

;Morrison, Australia's prime minister from 2018 to 2022, had set up a Weixin account through a third party on the mainland to gain the support of Mandarin-speaking voters in Australia ahead of the general election.

;

;The third party later legitimately sold the account.

;

;The Labor Party, in opposition at the time, concluded there was no Chinese foreign interference in Morrison's account, and said security agencies did not recommend any regulatory or legislative changes over the issue.

;

;That sparked criticism from analysts who said the WeChat allegations had turned national security into a “partisan political football game”.

;

;At the time, Morrison was positioning his coalition party as being “tough on China”.

;

;Australians see benefits of strong China ties but want Chinese apps banned: poll

;

;WeChat in its response emphasised the differences between its global and mainland versions: Weixin can only be used by a Chinese national and is governed by Chinese mainland law, while international users open WeChat accounts governed by Singaporean laws.

;

;It added that Weixin users, even in Australia, would be subjected to Chinese laws as well as local laws, but those users could switch to WeChat.

;

;The ongoing inquiry has received submissions from a range of sources, including academics who have called for an outright ban on China-linked WeChat and TikTok.

;

;Other observers say a blanket ban would hurt Australia's democracy. The prominent Australian cryptographer Vanessa Teague highlighted in her submission that platforms in Western liberal democracies had been found culpable of invading users' privacy.

; Thu, 27 Jul 2023 20:20:02 +0800 With US interest rates at a 22-year high, how will Beijing’s new central bank chief counter the toll on China?https://www.scmp.com/economy/china-economy/article/3229153/us-interest-rates-22-year-high-how-will-beijings-new-central-bank-chief-counter-toll-china?utm_source=rss_feed

;Ongoing interest rate increases by the US Federal Reserve underpin the first major challenge for China's newly appointed central bank governor tasked with defusing financial risks, curbing capital flight and getting the nation's sputtering economic recovery back on track.

;

;The US Federal Reserve lifted its interest rates to a range of 5.25 to 5.5 per cent on Wednesday, marking the 11th increase since early 2022 and the highest level in 22 years as the central bank attempts to cool the economy and ease price inflation.

;

;The US rate increases have added pressure on the yuan, another consideration that Beijing has to take into account, as there are rising risks in various parts of the economy, including bleak export prospects, growing deflation risks, a lack of business confidence, mounting local government debts, a beleaguered property market and heightened US-led de-risking pressure.

;

;“[Pan Gongsheng] has a reputation for regulation and compliance which may mean that shifts towards a more expansionary monetary policy could come in measured steps,” UOB Group said on Thursday after Pan only replaced Yi Gang as People's Bank of China (PBOC) governor on Tuesday.

;

;China's top leadership has loosened regulatory policies on property and big tech, and called for further private development in a Politburo meeting on Monday, after the country's sequential economic growth slowed to 0.8 per cent in the second quarter.

;

;The Politburo, the prime decision-making body of the Communist Party, ordered the basic stability of yuan exchange rate to be maintained, countercyclical policy adjustments to be enhanced and monetary support for innovation and market entities.

;

;Foreign investors offload Chinese debt for sixth straight month

;

;Pingan Securities said on Tuesday that it was the first time that the leadership had mentioned the exchange rate since the yuan started to depreciate against the US dollar last year. The yuan has fallen by 3.3 per cent against the US dollar since the start of this year.

;

;Over the past few weeks, China's central bank has delivered stronger than expected daily yuan fixings to stem currency weakness, and has also eased restrictions on foreign borrowing to encourage capital inflows.

;

;In June, the PBOC lowered a short-term lending rate for the first time in 10 months, with the national economic recovery running out of steam.

;

;Having set a growth target of “around 5 per cent” earlier this year, China's economy grew by 5.5 per cent, year on year, in the first half of 2023, but banks have lowered their full-year estimates to 5 per cent.

;

;Analysts now expect the PBOC to lend support to easing measures in the property market, although the central bank is likely to stick with a targeted approach.

;

;Anticipation that the US Federal Reserve could be ending its rate increase cycle means that there is more room for policymakers to ease monetary policy without adding depreciation pressure on the yuan.

;

;“I think Pan is very experienced within the system … he is a good candidate to balance these policy objectives, financial stability, exchange rate stability and stable growth of economy,” said Xia Le, chief economist for Asia at BBVA.

;

;“Pan will need to respond to the current issues, which are different from what Yi had to deal with.”

;

;Pan, who was already vice-governor of the PBOC and has been the head of the State Administration of Foreign Exchange since 2016, had said before this week's appointment that China would not follow the US in making large changes to its interest rates.

;
